### Module {#module .help-syntax-right-anchor}

Features:


- Autocomplete with customizable delay. Enhances [cmdline-completion](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=cmdline-completion) and
  manual ['wildchar'](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag='wildchar') pressing experience.
  Requires Neovim>=0.11, though Neovim>=0.12 is recommended.


- Autocorrect words as-you-type. Only words that must come from a fixed set of
  candidates (like commands and options) are autocorrected by default.


- Autopeek command range as-you-type. Shows a floating window with range lines
  along with customizable context lines.

What it doesn't do:


- Customization of command line UI. Use [vim.\_extui](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=vim._extui) (on Neovim>=0.12).


- Customization of autocompletion candidates. They are computed
  via [cmdline-completion](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=cmdline-completion).

#### Setup {#module-setup}


This module needs a setup with `require('mini.cmdline').setup({})` (replace `{}`
with your `config` table). It will create global Lua table `MiniCmdline` which
you can use for scripting or manually (with `:lua MiniCmdline.*`).

See [MiniCmdline.config](mini-cmdline.qmd#minicmdline.config) for `config` structure and default values.

You can override runtime config settings locally to buffer inside
`vim.b.minicmdline_config` which should have same structure as
`MiniCmdline.config`. See [mini.nvim-buffer-local-config](mini-nvim.qmd#mini.nvim-buffer-local-config) for more details.

#### Suggested option values {#module-suggestedoptionvalues}


Some options are set automatically (if not set before [MiniCmdline.setup()](mini-cmdline.qmd#minicmdline.setup)):

- ['wildmode'](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag='wildmode') is set to "noselect,full" for less intrusive autocompletion.
  Requires Neovim>=0.11 and enabled `config.autocomplete`.

- ['wildoptions'](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag='wildoptions') is set to "pum,fuzzy" to enable fuzzy matching.

#### Comparisons {#module-comparisons}



- [folke/noice.nvim](https://github.com/folke/noice.nvim):

    - Mostly focuses on visual aspects of the Command line.
      This modules is aimed to improve its workflow without changing UI.


- [nacro90/numb.nvim](https://github.com/nacro90/numb.nvim):

    - Designed to preview only a single line range defined by numbers.
      This module handles any form of [:range](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=:range) and [:range-offset](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=:range-offset) for both
      one and two line ranges.

    - Shows target line directly in the normal window.
      This module uses a dedicated floating window.


- Built-in [cmdline-autocompletion](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=cmdline-autocompletion) (on Neovim>=0.12):

    - This module on Neovim>=0.12 uses that as its base for autocompletion.
      Ont top of that it also provides customizable delay and predicate.


- Built-in [vim.\_extui](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=vim._extui) (on Neovim>=0.12):

    - Mostly focuses on visual aspects of the Command line.
      This modules is aimed to improve its workflow without changing UI.

#### Highlight groups {#module-highlightgroups}



- `MiniCmdlinePeekBorder` - border of autopeek window.

- `MiniCmdlinePeekLineNr` - line numbers in autopeek window.

- `MiniCmdlinePeekNormal` - basic foreground/background of autopeek window.

- `MiniCmdlinePeekSep` - statuscolumn separator in autopeek window.

- `MiniCmdlinePeekSign` - signs in autopeek window.

- `MiniCmdlinePeekTitle` - title of autopeek window.

#### Disabling {#module-disabling}


To disable acting in mappings, set `vim.g.minicmdline_disable` (globally) or
`vim.b.minicmdline_disable` (for a buffer) to `true`. Considering high number
of different scenarios and customization intentions, writing exact rules
for disabling module's functionality is left to user.
See [mini.nvim-disabling-recipes](mini-nvim.qmd#mini.nvim-disabling-recipes) for common recipes.

### config {#minicmdline.config .help-syntax-right-anchor}

<p align="center">`MiniCmdline.config`</p>
#### Defaults {#minicmdline.config-defaults}



  ```lua
  MiniCmdline.config = {
    -- Autocompletion: show `:h 'wildmenu'` as you type
    autocomplete = {
      enable = true,

      -- Delay (in ms) after which to trigger completion
      -- Neovim>=0.12 is recommended for positive values
      delay = 0,

      -- Custom rule of when to trigger completion
      predicate = nil,

      -- Whether to map arrow keys for more consistent wildmenu behavior
      map_arrows = true,
    },

    -- Autocorrection: adjust non-existing words (commands, options, etc.)
    autocorrect = {
      enable = true,

      -- Custom autocorrection rule
      func = nil,
    },

    -- Autopeek: show command's target range in a floating window
    autopeek = {
      enable = true,

      -- Number of lines to show above and below range lines
      n_context = 1,

      -- Custom rule of when to show peek window
      predicate = nil,

      -- Window options
      window = {
        -- Floating window config
        config = {},

        -- Function to render statuscolumn
        statuscolumn = nil,
      },
    },
  }
  ```

#### General {#minicmdline.config-general}



- Each feature is configured via separate table.

- Use `enable = false` to disable a feature.

#### Autocomplete {#minicmdline.config-autocomplete}


`config.autocomplete` is used to configure autocompletion: automatic show
of ['wildmenu'](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag='wildmenu').

`autocomplete.delay` defines a (debounce style) delay after which ['wildchar'](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag='wildchar')
is triggered to show wildmenu.
Default: 0. Note: Neovim>=0.12 is recommended for positive values if you
want to reduce flicker (thanks to [wildtrigger()](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=wildtrigger\(\))).

`autocomplete.predicate` defines a condition of whether to trigger completion
at the current command line state. Takes a table with input data and should
return `true` to show completion and `false` otherwise. Will be called before
the possible delay at current command line state.
Default: [MiniCmdline.default\_autocomplete\_predicate()](mini-cmdline.qmd#minicmdline.default_autocomplete_predicate).

Input data fields:

- <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<line\></span> `(string)` - current command line text. See [getcmdline()](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=getcmdline\(\)).

- <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<pos\></span> `(number)` - current command line column. See [getcmdpos()](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=getcmdpos\(\)).

- <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<line_prev\></span> `(string)` - command line text before the latest change.

- <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<pos_prev\></span> `(number)` - command line column before the latest cursor move.

Example of blocking completion based on completion type (as some may be slow):

  ```lua
  local block_compltype = { shellcmd = true }
  require('mini.cmdline').setup({
    autocomplete = {
      predicate = function()
        return not block_compltype[vim.fn.getcmdcompltype()]
      end,
    },
  })
  ```

Similar approach can be used to enable completion only for normal Ex commands.
Use `return vim.fn.getcmdtype() == ':'` as a predicate output.

#### Autocorrect {#minicmdline.config-autocorrect}


`config.autocorrect` is used to configure autocorrection: automatic adjustment
of bad words as you type them. This works only when appending single character
at the end of the command line. Editing already typed words does not trigger
autocorrect (allows correcting the autocorrection).

When to autocorrect is computed automatically based on [getcmdcomplpat()](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=getcmdcomplpat\(\)) after
every key press: if it doesn't add the character to completion pattern, then
the pattern before the key press is attempted to be corrected.
There is also an autocorrection attempt for the last word just before
executing the command.

Notes:

- This is intended mostly for fixing typos and not as a shortcut for fuzzy
  matching. Performing the latter automatically is too intrusive. Explicitly
  use fuzzy completion for that (set up by default).


- Default autocorrection is done only for words that must come from a fixed
  set of candidates (like commands and options) by choosing the one with
  the lowest string distance.
  See [MiniCmdline.default\_autocorrect\_func()](mini-cmdline.qmd#minicmdline.default_autocorrect_func) for details.


- Word that matches some Command-line [abbreviation](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=abbreviation) is not autocorrected.


- If current command expects only a single argument (like [:colorscheme](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=:colorscheme)), then
  autocorrection will happen only just before executing the command.

`autocorrect.func` is a function that can be used to customize autocorrection.
Takes a table with input data and should return a string with the correct word
or `nil` for no autocorrection. Default: [MiniCmdline.default\_autocorrect\_func()](mini-cmdline.qmd#minicmdline.default_autocorrect_func).

Input data fields:

- <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<word\></span> `(string)` - word to be autocorrected. Never empty string.

- <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<type\></span> `(string)` - word type. Output of [getcmdcompltype()](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=getcmdcompltype\(\)).

#### Autopeek {#minicmdline.config-autopeek}


`config.autopeek` is used to configure automatic peeking: show command's target
range in a floating window. The window will appear above command line and show
current buffer with the focus on left and right (if present and differs from
left) range lines.

`autopeek.n_context` defines how many lines to show above and below the target.
The range itself is visualized by default with the statuscolumn signs.
Default: 1.

`autopeek.predicate` defines a condition of whether to show peek window at
the current command line state. Takes a table with input data and should
return `true` to peek and `false` otherwise.
Will be called only if it is possible to parse range from the current command
line text and it is for buffer lines (no command or [:command-addr](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=:command-addr) is `lines`)
Default: [MiniCmdline.default\_autopeek\_predicate()](mini-cmdline.qmd#minicmdline.default_autopeek_predicate).

Input data fields:

- <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<left\></span> `(number)` - left range edge. Not necessarily smallest.

- <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<right\></span> `(number)` - right range edge. Same as `left` for a single line range.

- <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<cmd\></span> `(string)` - full command name. Can be empty string if no valid
  command is (yet) entered.

`autopeek.window` defines behavior of a peek window.
`autopeek.window.config` is a table defining floating window characteristics
or a callable returning such table.
It should have the same structure as in [nvim\_open\_win()](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=nvim_open_win\(\)).

`autopeek.window.statuscolumn` is a special function that can be used to
customize ['statuscolumn'](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag='statuscolumn') value for the peek window. Takes a table with input
data and should return a string to display for line [v:lnum](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=v:lnum).
Default: [MiniCmdline.default\_autopeek\_statuscolumn()](mini-cmdline.qmd#minicmdline.default_autopeek_statuscolumn).
Input data fields are the same as for `autopeek.predicate`.

Example of showing `<` and `>` signs on range lines:

  ```lua
  function(data)
    local n, l, r = vim.v.lnum, data.left, data.right
    local s = n == l and (n == r and '* ' or '< ') or n == r and '> ' or ''
    -- Needs explicit highlighting via `:h 'statusline'` syntax
    return '%#MiniCmdlinePeekSign#' .. s
  end
  ```

Notes:

- Peek window directly shows current buffer, which means that all its
  extmarks, virtual text, virtual lines, etc. are also shown.

- Non-zero context might work unreliably if there are virtual lines.

- Peeking intentionally hides Visual selection if Command-line mode is entered
  directly from it. Peeking `'<,'>` range already visualizes the selection.
  To disable autopeek for this case, add the following code BEFORE
  executing `require('mini.cmdline').setup()`:

    ```lua
    local disable = vim.schedule_wrap(function()
      local is_from_visual = vim.startswith(vim.fn.getcmdline(), "'<,'>")
      MiniCmdline.config.autopeek.enable = not is_from_visual
    end)
    local reenable = function() MiniCmdline.config.autopeek.enable = true end

    vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('CmdlineEnter', { callback = disable })
    vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('CmdlineLeave', { callback = reenable })
    ```

### default_autocomplete_predicate() {#minicmdline.default_autocomplete_predicate .help-syntax-right-anchor}

<p align="center">`MiniCmdline.default_autocomplete_predicate`(<span class="help-syntax-special">{data}</span>, <span class="help-syntax-special">{opts}</span>)</p>
Default autocompletion predicate

#### Parameters {#minicmdline.default_autocomplete_predicate-parameters}



<span class="help-syntax-special">{data}</span> `(table)` Input autocompletion data. As described in [MiniCmdline.config](mini-cmdline.qmd#minicmdline.config).

<span class="help-syntax-special">{opts}</span> `(table|nil)` Options. Reserved for future use.

#### Return {#minicmdline.default_autocomplete_predicate-return}


`(boolean)` If command line does not (yet) contain a letter - `false`,
  otherwise - `true`. This makes autopeek easier to use for a numerical range.

### default_autocorrect_func() {#minicmdline.default_autocorrect_func .help-syntax-right-anchor}

<p align="center">`MiniCmdline.default_autocorrect_func`(<span class="help-syntax-special">{data}</span>, <span class="help-syntax-special">{opts}</span>)</p>
Default autocorrection function


- Return input word if `opts.strict_type=true` and input `type` is not proper.

- Get candidates via `opts.get_candidates()`.
  Default: mostly via [getcompletion()](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=getcompletion\(\)) with empty pattern and input `type`.
  Exceptions are `help` and `option` types: both list all available candidates
  in their own ways.

- Choose the candidate with the lowest Damerauâ€“Levenshtein distance
  (smallest number of deletion/insertion/substitution/transposition needed
  to transform one word into another; slightly prefers transposition).
  Notes:

    - Type `'command'` also chooses from all valid candidate abbreviations.

    - Comparison is done both respecting and ignoring case.

#### Parameters {#minicmdline.default_autocorrect_func-parameters}



<span class="help-syntax-special">{data}</span> `(table)` Input autocorrection data. As described in [MiniCmdline.config](mini-cmdline.qmd#minicmdline.config).

<span class="help-syntax-special">{opts}</span> `(table|nil)` Options. Possible fields:

  - <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<strict_type\></span> `(boolean)` - whether to restrict output only for types which
    must have words from a fixed set of candidates (like command or option
    names). Note: does not include `help` type since [:help](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=:help) already has
    "sophisticated algorithm" to handle typos. Default: `true`.

  - <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<get_candidates\></span> `(function)` - source of candidates. Will be called
    with `data` as argument and should return array of string candidates to
    choose from.
    Default: for most types -  [getcompletion()](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=getcompletion\(\)) with empty pattern and
    input `type`; for `help` and `option` type - all available help tags and
    option names (long and short) respectively.

#### Return {#minicmdline.default_autocorrect_func-return}


`(string)` Autocorrected word.

<p align="center">`MiniCmdline.default_autopeek_predicate`(<span class="help-syntax-special">{data}</span>, <span class="help-syntax-special">{opts}</span>)</p>
Default autopeek predicate

<span class="help-syntax-special">{opts}</span> `(table|nil)` Options. Reserved for future use.

#### Return {#minicmdline.default_autopeek_predicate-return}


`(boolean)` If command defines [:command-preview](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=:command-preview) - `false`, otherwise - `true`.

  especially if ['inccommand'](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag='inccommand') is set to `split`.

### default_autopeek_statuscolumn() {#minicmdline.default_autopeek_statuscolumn .help-syntax-right-anchor}

<p align="center">`MiniCmdline.default_autopeek_statuscolumn`(<span class="help-syntax-special">{data}</span>, <span class="help-syntax-special">{opts}</span>)</p>
Default autopeek statuscolumn


- Show signs next to lines depending on their relation to peeked range.
  Highlighted with `MiniCmdlinePeekSign` group.

- Show line numbers for left and right parts of the range.
  Highlighted with `MiniCmdlinePeekLineNr` group.

- Separate statuscolumn and buffer text with dedicated separator character.
  Highlighted with `MiniCmdlinePeekSep` group.

Notes:

- Intended to only be used as a part of ['statuscolumn'](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag='statuscolumn') function, as it
  uses [v:lnum](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=v:lnum) and [v:virtnum](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=v:virtnum) to compute the output.

Example of adjusting a `mid` sign:

  ```lua
  local peek_stc_opts = { signs = { mid = '+' } }
  local peek_stc = function(data)
    return MiniCmdline.default_autopeek_statuscolumn(data, peek_stc_opts)
  end
  require('mini.cmdline').setup({
    autopeek = { window = { statuscolumn = peek_stc } },
  })
  ```

#### Parameters {#minicmdline.default_autopeek_statuscolumn-parameters}



<span class="help-syntax-special">{data}</span> `(table)` Input peek data. As described in [MiniCmdline.config](mini-cmdline.qmd#minicmdline.config).

<span class="help-syntax-special">{opts}</span> `(table|nil)` Options. Possible fields:

  - <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<signs\></span> `(table)` - signs to show. Possible fields:

      - <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<same\></span> `(string)` - on range if `left=right`. Default: `'ðŸ­¬'`.

      - <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<left\></span> `(string)`  - on `left` line.  Default: `'â”Œ'`.

      - <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<mid\></span> `(string)`   - inside range.  Default: `'â”Š'`.

      - <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<right\></span> `(string)` - on `right` line. Default: `'â””'`.

      - <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<out\></span> `(string)` - outside of range. Default: `''` (no sign).

      - <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<virt\></span> `(string)` - virtual line. Default: `'â€¢'`.

      - <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<wrap\></span> `(string)` - wrapped line. Default: `'â†³'`.

  - <span class="help-syntax-keys">\<sep\></span> `(string)` - string to put at the end to separate statuscolumn and
    buffer text. Default: `'â”‚'`

  Note: Any sign and separator should have every `%` escaped as `%%` (due to its
  special meaning in ['statuscolumn'](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag='statuscolumn')).
